data.title: Did the architect have a mental lapse or a brain freeze?
data.text: After two years of construction, the new Government Center station opened this Spring.  It is very impressive and efficient but very antiseptic in appearance.  The glass walls on the street level are a nice touch and give a feeling of open space.  But.....would you believe that in this busy station where thousands travel through daily, there is only ONE RESTROOM which is locked and hidden from sight.  What must the many visitors to our capitol city think?  It took a bit of sleuthing but I finally located THE RESTROOM on the main level behind the information booth which was not occupied.  There is a small sign which says restroom and another sign M/F.  The door was locked & the person inside said they would be right out.  It was an MBTA employee who emerged & told me indeed that was the only restroom and you needed a key.  Since he worked for the T, he had a key and opened the door for me.  I can't believe with all the planning that went into the new station that no one realized the need for restroom for the commuters!  Shame! Shame!

data.title: Easy reasonable long term parking - nice staff
data.text: I parked here for 4 days - and for Boston - $15/day is not bad.  My battery had died and took forever to get AAA to process my request on the phone.  One of the staff of the garage charged my car and helped me out.  Very helpful.

data.title: Location is the ONLY thing this garage has going for it.
data.text: This garage has a great location in downtown Boston. It is close to the Boston Garden, Faneuil Hall and the local business offices. I recently became a monthly parker and had to pay for three months in in advance $1,125. The attendant in the office was not very cordial and I hope I don't have to deal with him again. The garage always appears to be under construction and large areas of the garage are taken out of service. However, it never looks like anything is ever improved. The garage is dirty, the stairwells smell like urine, the spaces are small and your car will most assuredly get many dings and scratches. It's great if you like exercise because they usually only have one elevator out of four working and you can wait several minutes. I will say that they have the lowest monthly rate in the area, but it is also the worse garage I have ever used in Boston.

data.title: Key to the city
data.text: No matter where it seems your going in the city. The dump called the government center is always there. Enjoy the drug addicts make there beds for the night and the building full of the wonder smell of urine. But you can't not visit it if you go any where in the city.

data.title: ugly award-winning(!) 60s building.  Walk past (or through), do not stop.
data.text:
Unless someone's doing a performance outside this really isn't worth the time.  So just walk past, or walk through if you need to but don't detour for it.

Won awards for architecture (though admittedly one of them was from the city itself)

data.title: Pass through area to Faneuil Hall
data.text: We walked through this area several times on our way from Government Center "T" stop to Faneuil Hall and harbor area.  It was not a highlight of our trip and could be sketchy at night.  The architecture style from the 60's is not very interesting.

data.title: Not a highlight
data.text:
I passed by several times during my stay in downtown. It's very close to Quincy Market. The architecture style from the 60's is not very interesting. Buildings are very large. 
Definitely is not a highlight.

data.title: Feo edificio
data.text: Un edificio feo, mal diseñado, que no tiene nada que ver con la ciudad. Cerca esta el Quincy Market que es tan lindo y hace recordar nuevamente lo feo que el government center

data.title: Retorno à hist[oria
data.text: Parece que ao andar pelas ruas deste local, voltamos à hist[oria, e repensamos o que este povo fez para criar sua noção de cidadania. Povo valente, forte.
